sentence: Seldom do we see such dedication in young athletes.
explanation: Inversion with 'seldom' requires the auxiliary verb before the subject.

sentence: Had I known about the party, I would have attended.
explanation: This is an inverted conditional sentence, equivalent to 'If I had known'.

sentence: Not only did he finish the race, but he also won it.
explanation: Inversion with 'not only' requires the auxiliary verb before the subject.

sentence: No sooner had she arrived than the phone rang.
explanation: Inversion with 'no sooner... than' requires the auxiliary verb before the subject.

sentence: Little did he know the challenges that lay ahead.
explanation: Inversion with 'little' (meaning 'not much') requires the auxiliary verb before the subject.

sentence: Only when the sun set did they decide to leave.
options: They decided to leave only when the sun set
Only when the sun set they decided to leave
Did they decide to leave only when the sun set
Only when the sun did set
explanation: Inversion with 'only when' occurs in the main clause, not the 'only' clause.

sentence: Such was the impact of the speech that everyone was moved.
explanation: Inversion with 'such' emphasizes the degree of something.

sentence: Under no circumstances should you open that door.
idiom: Under no circumstances should you open
options: You should open under no circumstances
Under no circumstances you should open
Should you open under no circumstances
You should not open under any circumstances
correct: Under no circumstances should you open
explanation: Inversion with negative expressions like 'under no circumstances' requires the auxiliary verb before the subject.

sentence: Rarely have I seen such a beautiful painting.
explanation: Inversion with 'rarely' requires the auxiliary verb before the subject.

sentence: No sooner had he finished his work than he went home.
explanation: Inversion with 'no sooner... than' requires the auxiliary verb before the subject.

sentence: Hardly had she left when it started to rain.
explanation: Inversion with 'hardly... when' requires the auxiliary verb before the subject.

sentence: So successful was the project that it was expanded globally.
explanation: Inversion with 'so + adjective/adverb' emphasizes the degree of something.

sentence: Never before has technology advanced so rapidly.
explanation: Inversion with 'never before' requires the auxiliary verb before the subject.

sentence: On no account are you to disclose this information.
idiom: On no account are you to disclose
options: You are on no account to disclose
On no account you are to disclose
Are you on no account to disclose
You are not to disclose on any account
correct: On no account are you to disclose
explanation: Inversion with 'on no account' requires the auxiliary verb before the subject.

sentence: Were I to win the lottery, I would travel the world.
explanation: This is an inverted conditional sentence, equivalent to 'If I were to win'.

sentence: Only by working together can we achieve our goals.
idiom: Only by working together can we achieve
options: We can achieve our goals only by working together
Only by working together we can achieve
Can we achieve our goals only by working together
We can only achieve by working together
correct: Only by working together can we achieve
explanation: Inversion with 'only by' occurs in the main clause.

sentence: Not until all the guests had left did she finally relax.
idiom: Not until all the guests had left
options: She finally relaxed not until all the guests had left
Not until all the guests had left she finally relaxed
Did she finally relax not until all the guests had left
She did finally relax not until all the guests had left
correct: Not until all the guests had left
explanation: Inversion with 'not until' occurs in the main clause.

sentence: So quickly did he run that he broke the world record.
explanation: Inversion with 'so + adverb' emphasizes the degree of something.

sentence: Should you require any further assistance, please do not hesitate to ask.
explanation: This is an inverted conditional sentence, equivalent to 'If you require'.

sentence: In no way is he responsible for the accident.
idiom: In no way is he responsible
options: He is in no way responsible
In no way he is responsible
Is he in no way responsible
He is not responsible in any way
correct: In no way is he responsible
explanation: Inversion with 'in no way' requires the auxiliary verb before the subject.

sentence: Nowhere else will you find such a diverse collection of art.
explanation: Inversion with 'Nowhere else' requires the auxiliary verb before the subject.

sentence: At no time was the president aware of the secret plan.
idiom: At no time was the president
options: The president was at no time
At no time the president was
Was the president at no time
At no time was the president
correct: At no time was the president
explanation: Inversion with 'At no time' requires the auxiliary verb before the subject.

sentence: Were she to accept the offer, she would have to relocate.
explanation: This is an inverted conditional, equivalent to 'If she were to accept'.

sentence: It was his arrogance that I found so irritating.
explanation: This is a cleft sentence used for emphasis, starting with 'It was... that...'

sentence: What I need is a long holiday, not more work.
explanation: This is a 'wh-' cleft sentence used to emphasize the object of the need.

sentence: Having been warned about the storm, they stayed indoors.
explanation: A perfect participle clause ('Having been' + past participle) is used to show that one action happened before another.

sentence: Exhausted from the journey, he went straight to bed.
explanation: A past participle clause at the beginning of a sentence can explain the reason for the main action.

sentence: It is imperative that the matter be investigated immediately.
idiom: It is imperative that the matter be
explanation: The subjunctive 'be' is used after expressions like 'It is imperative that...'

sentence: The harder you study, the more you will learn.
explanation: This is a double comparative structure: 'The + comparative, the + comparative'.

sentence: A great writer he was, but a difficult person to know.
explanation: This is an example of fronting, where a part of the sentence is moved to the front for emphasis.

sentence: Not for a moment did I think I would get the job.
idiom: Not for a moment did I think
options: I did not think for a moment
Not for a moment I thought
Not for a moment did I think
I thought not for a moment
correct: Not for a moment did I think
explanation: Inversion is used after the negative expression 'Not for a moment'.

sentence: Only after his speech did I understand the full situation.
idiom: Only after his speech did I understand
options: I understood only after his speech
Only after his speech I understood
Only after his speech did I understand
I did understand only after his speech
correct: Only after his speech did I understand
explanation: When a sentence starts with 'Only after', the main clause is inverted.

sentence: Should the situation worsen, we have a contingency plan.
explanation: This inverted conditional is a more formal way of saying 'If the situation should worsen'.

sentence: Built in the 16th century, the castle is a major tourist attraction.
options: It was built in the 16th century,
explanation: A past participle clause is used to give more information about the noun 'the castle'.

sentence: The board proposed that the new policy be implemented next year.
idiom: The board proposed that the new policy be
explanation: The subjunctive 'be' is used after verbs of suggestion like 'propose'.

sentence: The sooner we leave, the earlier we will arrive.
explanation: This is a double comparative structure: 'The + comparative, the + comparative'.

sentence: Into the room walked the mysterious stranger.
options: The mysterious stranger walked into the room
Into the room the mysterious stranger walked
Walked into the room the mysterious stranger
explanation: This is an example of fronting a prepositional phrase for dramatic effect, followed by inversion.

sentence: Not a single mistake did she make in the entire performance.
idiom: Not a single mistake did she make
options: She did not make a single mistake
Not a single mistake she made
A single mistake she did not make
Not a single mistake did she make
correct: Not a single mistake did she make
explanation: Inversion is used after the negative expression 'Not a single...'

sentence: The problem is thought to be more complex than initially assumed.
idiom: The problem is thought to be
options: The problem is thought to be
It is thought the problem to be
The problem, it is thought, is
correct: The problem is thought to be
explanation: This is a common complex passive structure used in formal or academic writing.

sentence: On no condition are you to leave this room.
idiom: On no condition are you to
options: You are on no condition to
On no condition you are to
Are you on no condition to
On no condition are you to
correct: On no condition are you to
explanation: Inversion with the negative expression 'On no condition' requires the auxiliary verb before the subject.
